question: High-frequency generators that have higher x-ray quantity and quality
Single-phase power in which the voltage varies from zero to iys maximum value.
Three-phase, six pulse power whose voltage supplied to the x-ray tube never falls below 86 % of peak value.
Three-phase,12 pulse power whose voltage supplied to the x-ray tube never falls below 96 % of peak value.
Protective covering of gelatin that encloses an emulsion.
Increased incidence of a disease; constant number of cases after minimal latent period.
Incidence of malignant disease in a population within 1 year for a given dose ; expressed as number number of cases / 10^6 persons/rem
A. Energy transferred from ionizing radiation per unit mass of irradiated material ; expressed in rad (100 erg/g) or gray (1 J/kg).
Characteristics of a subject that affects subject contrast.
Transfer of energy from an electromagnetic field to matter; removal of x-rays from a beam via the photoelectric effect.
Process  by which ultrasound transfer energy to tissue through conversion of acoustic energy heat.
Thermalization of tissue through absorption of ultrasound, energy; expressed as a rise in temperature ( degree celsius)
Rate of change of velocity over time
Constant rate at which objects falling to the Earth accelerate.
Chemical used in the stop bath
Chemical, usually acetic acid in the fixer and sodium carbonate in the developer , used to neutralized the developer and swell the gelatin.
Data can be stored or accessed at random from anywhere in main memory in approximately equal amounts of time, regardless of where the data are located.
Area on the anode target that is exposed to electrons from the tube current.
Radiation sickness that occurs in humans after whole-body doses of 1 Gy (100 rad) or more of ionizing radiation delivered over a short time.
Nitrogenous organic base that attaches to a deoxyibose molecule
Protective coating of gelatin that encloses the emulsion.
Oxidation that occurs when air is introduced into the developer after it is mixed, handled, and stored.
Phosphorescence in an intensifying screen.
Pattern of change in radiosensitivity as a function of phase in the cell cycle.
Practice of moving the image receptor 10 to 15 cm from the patient so that fewer scattered x-rays interact with the image receptor, thereby enhancing contrast.
Principle that states that radiation radiation exposure should kept As Low As Reasonably Achievable , when economic and social factors are taken into account.
Computer-adapted mathematical calculation applied to raw data during image reconstruction.
Alloy of aluminum , nickel , and cobalt ; one of the more useful magnets produced from ferromagnetic material.
Particulate form of ionizing radiation that consists of two protons and two neutrons ; nucleus of helium emitted from the nucleus of a radioactive atom.
Oscillation of electricity in both directions within a conductor.
Filter that transmits light with wavelengths longer than 55o nm, which is above the spectral response of blue-sensitive film.
Scientific society of medical physicits.
answer: American Association of Physicists in Medicine (AAPM)

question: Profesiona society of medical physicists
Professional society of radiologists and medical physicists.
Scientific and professional society of  radiographers.
Device that measures current.
SI unit of electric charge: 1 A = 1 C/s.
Width of a waveform.
Process of synthesizing smaller molecules into a larger macromolecule.
Third phase of mitosis, during which chromatids repel one another and migrate along the mitotic spindle to opposite sides of the cell.
Technique by which graphics on the console guide the technologist in selection of a desired kVp and mAs.
Fluoroscopic process by which the x-ray examination is guided toward visualization of vessels.
Unit of measure of wavelength: 1 Å = 10-10 m.
Positively charged side of an x-ray tube that contains the target.
Human characteristics.
Proteins produced by the body in response to the presence of foreign antigens, such as bacteria or viruses.
Molecular configuration of an antibody that attacks a particular type of invasive or infectious agent.
Simple beam-restricting device that attaches a lead-lined metal diaphragm to the head of the x-ray tube.
Circular opening for the patient in the gantry of a computed tomographic or magnetic resonance imaging system.
Fixed collimation of a diagnostic x-ray tube, as in an aperture diaphragm.
Variable opening before the lens of a cine or photospot camera.
Attribute that refers to the fact that the image does not deteriorate with age but remains in its original state.
X-ray beam pattern that usually is shaped like a square or a rectangle, and that is used in conventional radiography and fluoroscopy.
Part of a computer that handles raw data and performs the mathematical calculations necessary to reconstruct a digital image.
Unintended optical density on a radiograph or another film-type image receptor.
Referring to the body habitus of a patient who is small and frail.
Smallest particle of an element that cannot be divided or broken by chemical means.
Number of protons plus number of neutrons in the nucleus.
Mass of neutral atom of an element, expressed as one-twelfth the mass of carbon, which has an arbitrarily assigned value of 12.
Relative mass of a specific isotope of an element.
Number of protons in the nucleus.
Shrinking of a tissue or organ.
Reduction in radiation intensity results from absorption and scattering.
Feature on a fluoroscope that allows the radiologist to select an image-brightness level that is subsequently maintained automatically by varying the kVp, the mas, or both.
Feature that determines radiation exposure during radiography in most x-ray imaging systems.
Principle stating that the voltage received and the voltage provided are directly related to the number of turns of the transformer enclosed by the respective connections.
Transformer located in the operating console that controls the kVp; it consists of one winding of wire and varies voltage and current by self-induction.
Measure of radiographic contrast.
Conventional tomography in which the plane of the image is parallel to the long axis of the body; this results in sagittal and coronal images.
Perpendicular to the long axis of the body.
X-rays that have interacted with an object and are deflected backward.
Number of times per second that the electron beam can be modulated.
Stem cells that mature as they migrate to the surface of the epidermis.
Optical density inherent in the base of the film.
Average density from an unexposed area of the strips.
Area that serves as a mechanical support for the active phosphor layer in a radiographic intensifying screen.
A woman's first radiographic examination of her breasts, used for comparison with all future mammograms.
Each zinc-copper plate formation in a voltaic pile.
Central line that represents maximal ultrasound or x-ray intensity.
Ability of an x-ray beam to penetrate tissue.
Device that restricts the size the x-ray field to only the anatomical structure interest.
Device that provides a means restricting the size of an x-ray field.
Special name for the SI units of radioactivity. One becquerel (BQ) is equal to disintegration per second.
lonizing radiation with characteristics of an electron; emitted from the nucleus of a radioactive atom.
Number system with only two digits, 0 or 1.
Chemical reactions at the molecular level.
Configuration of pairs of serial changers used with two orthogonal x-ray sources.
Magnets that has two poles.
Number of bits used to reproduce image gray levels (Ex., 8 bits = 28 = 256 gray levels).
Smallest unit of measure in computer storage capacity
General size and shape of a patient.
Radiation oncology in which the source of radiation is on or in the body.
X-ray that results from interaction of the projectile electron with a target nucleus; braking radiation.
Ability of the image intensifier to increase the illumination level of the image.
Ratio of incident radiation to transmitted radiation through a grid; ratio of patient dose with and without a grid.
Protective cover that automatically shields the Bucky slot opening during fluoroscopic examinations when the Bucky tray is at the foot of the table.
Acetate added to the fixer to maintain a constant pH.
Alkali compound in the developer that enhances the action of the developing agent by controlling the concentration of hydrogen ions.
Group of eight bits; represents one character or digit.
Rigid holder that contains the film and screens.
Conventional method of capturing images with image-intensified fluoroscopes.
Process that creates energy for a cell by breaking down molecular nutrients that are brought to and diffused through the cell membrane.
Electron beam tube designed for a two-dimensional display of signals.
Stream of electrons.
Negative side of the x-ray tube; contains the filament and the focusing cup.
Process by which normal cells produce a visible colony in a short time.
Average time from one mitosis to another.
Principle that all plants and animals contain cells as their basic functional units.
Basic unit of all living matter.
Agency responsible for a national electronic radiation control program. Known as the Bureau of Radiological Health (BRH) before 1982.
answer: Center for Diseases and Radiological Health (CDHR)

question: X-ray beam composed of x-rays that travel along the center of the useful x-ray beam.

Form of acute radiation syndrome caused by radiation doses of 50 Gy (5000 rad) or more of ionizing radiation that results in failure of the central nervous system, followed by death within a few hours to several days.
Processing hardware in large computers.
Center of the x-ray beam that interacts with the image receptor.
Force that causes an electron to travel straight and leave the atom.
Force that keeps an electron in orbit.
Graph of optical density versus log relative response; H & D curve.
X-ray released as a result of the photoelectric effect; its discrete energies are determined by the respective electron binding energy.
Solid-state device that converts visible light photons to electrons.
Sequestering agent.
Energy released by a chemical reaction.
Artifact produced by chemical contamination of the developer.
Alphabetic abbreviation for an element.
Tiny piece of semiconductor material.
Breakage of a chromatid.
Film used in Cinefluorography.
Recording of fluoroscopic images on movie film.
Scattering of x-rays with no loss of energy. Also called Coherent, Rayleigh, or Thompson scattering.
A chemical, usually ammonium thiosulfate, that is added to the fixer to remove undeveloped silver bromine from the emulsion.
Moist desquamation in radiation therapy.
Square core ferromagnetic material built up of laminated layers of iron; it helps to reduced energy losses caused by eddy currents.
Time it takes the rotor to rest after use.
Series of three consecutive nucleotide bases in the DNA
Restriction of the useful x-ray beam to reduce patient dose and improve image contrast.
Device used to restrict x-ray beam size and shape.
Device that acts like a switch, converting an alternating-current generator to a direct-current generator.
Material inserted between an x-ray source and a patient to shape the intensity of the ay beam. An x-ray beam filter is designed to make the remnant beam more  uniform in intensity.
Device that maintains close screen-film contact when the cassette is closed and latched.
The act of flattening soft tissue to improve optical density.
Scattering of x-rays that results in ionization and loss of energy.
Interaction between an x-ray and a loosely bound outer-shell electron that results in ionization and x-ray scattering.
Radiographic technique that uses a photostimulable phosphor as the image receptor and an area beam.
Creation of a cross-sectional tomographic section of the body with a rotating fan beam, a detector array, and computed reconstruction.
Radiation dose in a single slice over a 10-cm length so that dose delivered beyond the selected slice thickness is included.
Use of a highly complex pattern recognition.
Transfer of heat by molecular agitation.
Material that allows heat or electric current to flow.
Misalignment of cones that causes one side of the radiograph to not be exposed because the edge of the cone may interfere with the x-ray beam.
Circular metal tube that attaches to x-ray tube housing to limit the beam size and shape.
Modifications of the aperture diaphragm.
Tissue that binds tissue and organs together.
Shields that are flat and are placed directly on the patient's gonads.
Program that includes administrative protocols for the continual improvement of mammographic quality.
Compound used as an aid for imaging internal organs with x-rays.
Ratio of radiographic contrast with a grid to that without a grid.
Difference between the step with an average optical density closest to 2.2 and the step with an average optical density closest to, but not less than,0.5.
Agent that enhances differences between anatomical structures.
Ability to distinguish between and to image similar tissues.
Degree of difference between the light and dark areas of a radiograph.
Area where personnel occupancy and activity are subject to control and supervision for the purpose of radiation protection.
Transfer of heat by the movement of hot matter to a colder place.
Rate at which x-ray is transformed into light in an intensifying screen.
Ratio of illumination intensity the output phosphor to radiation intensity incident on the input phosphor.
Type of vacuum tube in use today that allows x-ray intensity and energy to be selected separately and accurately.
Particulate and electromagnetic radiation emitted by the sun and the stars.
SI unit of electric charge.
SI unit of radiation exposure. 2.58 x 10 -4  C/kg = 1R.
Joining of magnetic fields produced by the primary and secondary coils.
Chemical union between atoms formed by sharing one or more pairs of electrons.
The more efficient use of silver in an emulsion to produce the same optical density per unit exposure.
Forerunner of modern fluorescent, neon, and x-ray tubes.
Grid on which lead strips run parallel to the lo10ng and short axes.
Process of side spurs created by irradiation and attached to a neighboring macromolecule or to another segment of the same molecule.
Device in an automatic processor that transports film from one tank to the next.
Process that occurs during meiosis wherein chromatids exchange chromosomal material.
Extremely cold liquid.
Three-dimensional, cross-linked structure of silver, bromine, and iodine atoms.
Former unit of radioactivity. Expressed as 1 Ci = 3.7 x 1010 disintegrations per second = 3.7 x 1010 Bq.
Nickname for an ionization chamber-type survey meter.
Protoplasm that exists outside the cell's nucleus.
Nitrogenous organic base that attaches to a  deoxyribose molecule.
Computer-controlled amplifier and switching device to which the signal from each radiation detector of a multi-slice spiral  computed tomography scanning system is connected.
System of numbers based on multiples of 10.
Instrument that measures the optical density of exposed film.
The difference between the step with an average optical density closest to 2.2 and the step with an average optical density closest to, but not less than, 0.5
Molecule that carries the genetic information necessary for cell replication; the target molecule of radiobiology.
Any secondary quantity derived from combination of one or more of three base quantities, such as mass, length, and time.
Ulceration and denudation of the skin.
Degree of sharpness of structural lines on a radiograph.
Percentage of x-rays absorbed by the image receptor.
Group of detectors and the interspace material used to separate them; the image receptor in computed tomography.
Biologic response whose severity varies with radiation dose. A dose threshold usually, exists.
A chemical, usually phenidone, hydroquinone, or Metol, that reduces exposed silver ions to atomic silver.
Stage of processing during which the latent image is converted to a manifest image.
Artifact that results from reduction of crystals that had not been exposed to metallic silver caused by the lack of a restrainer.
Examination performed on patients with symptoms or elevated risk factors for breast cancer.
Lead-lined housing enclosing an x-ray tube that shields leakage radiation to less than 100 mR/hr at 1 m.
Device that restricts an x-ray beam to a fixed size.
Two-colored stain that appears as a curtain effect on the radiograph.
Standard that enables imaging systems from different manufacturers to communicate.
answer: DICOM (Digital Imaging and Communications in Medicine)

question: Different degrees of absorption in different tissues that result in image contrast and formation of the x-ray image.
Digital x-ray imaging system that produces a series of dynamic images with the use of an area x-ray beam and an image intensifier.

Static images produced with a fan x-ray beam intercepted by a linear array of radiation detectors or an area x-ray beam intercepted by a photostimulable phosphor plate or a direct-capture solid-state device.
Nonmagnetic materials that are unaffected when brought into a magnetic field.
Property that allows the base of radiographic film to maintain its size and shape during use and processing, so it does not contribute to image distortion.
Vacuum tube with two electrodes-a cathode and anode.
Referring on a molecule with areas of opposing electric charge.
Flow of electricity in only one direction within conductor.
Effect of radiation that occurs when ionizing radiation interacts directly with a particularly radiosensitive molecule.
Electric Motor in which many turns of wire are used for the current loop and many bar magnets are used to create the external magnetic field.
Film used without intensifying screens.
A sugar
Process of separating a whole into parts.
Unequal magnification of different portions of the same object.
Radiation quantity that is used for radiation protection and that expresses dose on a common scale for all radiation. Expressed in rem or Sievert (Sv)
Product of computed tomography dose index (CTDI) and slice thickness. Depends only on selected computed tomography (CT) parameters and does not reflect patient dose.
Maximum permissible occupational dose.
Amount of radiant energy absorbed by an irradiated object.
Instrument that detects and measures exposure to ionizing radiation.
The practice of measuring the intensity of radiation
The practice of measuring the intensity of radiation.
Examination of the colon that uses air and barium for contrast.
Radiographic film that has an emulsion coating on both sides of the base and a layer of supercoat over each emulsion.
Configuration of DNA that is shaped like a ladder twisted about an imaginary axis like a spring.
That dose of radiation that is expected to double the number of genetic mutations in a generation.
Single-emulsion film that is exposed to ultraviolet light or blue light through the existing radiograph to produce a copy.
Range of values that can be displayed by an imaging system; shades of gray.
Radiation response that occurs within minutes or days after radiation exposure.
Current that opposes the magnetic field that induced it, creating a loss of transformer efficiency.
Accentuation of the interface between different tissues.
Mathematical expression of the ability of the computed tomographic scanner to reproduce a high-contrast edge with accuracy.
Weighted average atomic number for the different elements of a material.

Sum of specified tissues of the products of equivalent dose in a tissue (HT) and the weighting factor for the tissue (WT). Effective dose is a method of converting a nonuniform radiation dose, as when a protective apron is worn, to a dose, with respect to risk, as if the whole body were exposed.

Sum of the products of the dose equivalent to a tissue (HT) and the weighting factors (WT) applicable to each of the tissues irradiated. The values (WT) are different for effective dose and effective dose equivalent.
Area projected onto the patient and the image receptor.
Safeguard against the irradiation of an unsuspected pregnancy.
Path of electron flow from the generating source through the various components and back again.
Flow of electrons.
Lines of force exerted on charged ions in the tissues by the electrodes that cause charged particles to move from one pole to another.
Work that can be done when an electron or an electronic charge moves through an electric potential.
Form of energy created by the activity of electrons and other subatomic particles in motion.
Process of adding or removing electrons from a substance.
Object that has too few or too many electrons.
Electrical terminal or connector.
Coil or wire wrapped around an iron core that intensifies the magnetic field.
Type of energy in x-rays, radio waves, microwaves, and visible light.
Oscillating electric and magnetic fields that travel in a vacuum with of light. Includes x-rays, gamma rays, and some nonionizing radiation (such as ultraviolet, visible, infrared and Radio waves).
Continuum of electromagnetic energy.
Electric potential; measured in volts (V).
Strength of attachment of an electron to the nucleus.
Engineering aspects of maintaining proper electron travel.
Momentum of a particle of an atom in a fixed pattern.
Unit of energy equal to the an electron acquires from a potential difference of 1 V.
Elementary particle with one negative charge. Electrons surround the positively charged nucleus and determine the chemical properties of the atom.
Study of fixed or stationary electric charge.
Atoms that have the same atomic number and the same chemical properties. Substance that cannot be reduced further without changing its chemical properties.
Characteristic mass of an element determined by the relative abundance of isotopes and their respective atomic masses.
image that is made to appear longer than it really is because the inclined object is not located on the central x-ray beam.
Damage that occurs as the result of exposure of an organism to ionizing radiation during its embryonic stage of development.
Material with which x-rays or light photons from screens interact and transfer information.
Channel or series of channels that allows the nucleus to communicate with the cytoplasm.
Orbits around the nucleus that contain a designated number of electrons.
Technique that uses the two x-ray beams alternately to provide a subtraction image that results from differences in photoelectric interaction.
ability to do work; measured in Joules.
Roller that grips the film to begin is trip through the processor.
X-ray exposure to the skin; expressed in milliroentgen (mR).
Molecule that is needed in small quantities to allow a biochemical reaction to continue, even though it does not directly enter into the reaction.
Study of the occurrence, distribution, and causes of disease in humans.
Loss of hair.
Covering Tissue that lines all exposed surfaces of the body, both exterior and interior.
Unit of energy and work.
Sunburn-like reddening of the skin.
Red blood cell.
Electrons used in reduction/ oxidation produces electrons.
Difference between observed and expected numbers of cases.
Addition of energy to a system achieved by raising the energy of electrons with the use of x-rays.
X-rays that remain after the beam exits through the patient.
Superscript or power to which 10 is raised in scientific notation.
Power of 10 notation.
Matter that intercepts radiation and absorb part or all of it; irradiated matter.
Factors that influence and determine the quantity and quality of x-radiation to which the patient is exposed.
Ability of a radiographic unit to produce a constant radiation output for various combinations of mA and exposure time.
Measure of the ionization produced in air by x-rays or gamma rays. Quantity of radiation intensity expressed in roentgen (R ), Coulombs per kilogram (C/ kg), or air kerma (Gy).
Time required to end an exposure.
Electrons that bounce off the focal spot and land on other areas of the target.
Estimation of a value beyond the range of known values.
Design in which exposure factors are adjusted automatically to the highest mA at the shortest exposure time allowed by the high-voltage generator.
X-ray beam pattern used in computed tomography and digital radiography; projected as a slit.
The start of the transport system, where the film to be processed is inserted into the automatic processor in the darkroom.
Material that is strongly attracted by a magnet and that usually can be permanently magnetized by exposure to a magnetic field.
Image matrix size provided by digital x-ray imaging systems.
Interactions among different energies, forces, or masses that cannot be seen but can be described mathematically.
Principally that states that if the optical density on a radiograph is to be increased with the use of kVp, an increase in kVp by 15% is equivalent to doubling of the mAs.
Part of the cathode that emits electrons , resulting in a tube current.
Collection of data or information that is treated as a unit by the computer.
Pack of photographic film used for approximate measurement of radiation exposure to radiation workers. It is the most widely used and most economical type of personnel radiation monitor.
Distribution of silver halide grains in an emulsion.
Process by which an image acquired during computed tomography and stored in computer memory is reconstructed.
Removal of low-energy x-rays from the useful beam with aluminum or another metal. It result in increased beam quality and reduced patient dose.
Finely collimated x-ray beam, single-detector assembly that translates across the patient and rotates between successive translation.
Principle that states an increase of 5 % in the kVp may be accompanied by a 30 % reduction in the mAs to produce the same optical density at a slightly reduced contrast scale.
Stage of processing during which the silver halide not exposed to radiation is dissolved and removed from the emulsion.
Emission of visible light only during stimulation.
Cycle in a television picture tube whereby the electron beam creates the television optical signal and then immediately fades.
Device used to image moving anatomical structures with x-rays.
Imaging modality that provides a continuous image of the motion of internal structures while the x-ray tube is energized. Real-time imaging.
Ratio of the number of light photons at the output phosphor to the number of x-rays at the input phosphor.
Region of the anode target in which electrons interact to produce x-rays.
Blurred region on the radiograph over which the technologist has little control.
Radiographic grid constructed so that the grid strips converge on an imaginary line.
Metal should that surrounds the filament.
Development of silver grain that contains no useful information.
Unintended optical density on a radiograph that reduces contrast through light or chemical contamination.
That which changes the motion of an object; a push or a pull. Expressed in newtons (N).
Reduction in image size; related to the angle of inclination of the object.
Unit in which the x-ray source rotates but the detector assembly does not.
Numeric value expressed by dividing one number by another.
Radiation dose delivered at the same dose in equal portions at regular intervals.
Uncharged molecule that contains a single unpaired electron in the valence shell.
Number of cycles or wavelengths of a simple harmonic motion per unit time. Expressed in Hertz (Hz). 1 Hz = 1 cycle/s.
Imaginary pivot point about which the x-ray tube and the image receptor move.
Width of the profile at half its maximum value.
Circuit in which the negative half-cycle corresponding to the inverse voltage is reversed, so a positive voltage is always directed across the x-ray tube.
The three principles of inertia, force, and action/reaction established by Isaac Newton.
The three primary constituents of an atom - electrons, photons, and neutrons.
Portion of the computed tomographic or magnetic resonance imaging system that accommodates the patient and source or the detector assemblies.
Form of acute radiation syndrome that appears in humans at a threshold dose of about 10 Gy (1000 rad). It is characterized by nausea, diarrhea, and damage to the cells lining the intestines.
Radiation detection and radiation measuring instrument that detects individual ionizations. It is the primary radiation survey instrument for nuclear medicine facilities.
Part of the emulsion that provides mechanical support for the silver halide crystals by holding them uniformly dispersed in place.
See Cell cycle time.
Oogonium or spermatogonium.
Effect of radiation that is seen in an individual and in subsequent unexposed generations.
Average gonadal dose given to members of the population who are of childbearing age.
Reproductive cell.
Average radiation dose to glandular tissue.
Graph that shows the relationship of light output to temperature change.
Human polysaccharide.
Exposure to the reproductive organs.
Slope of the tangent at any point characteristic curve.
Scavenger cell used to fight bacteria.
Special name for the SI unit of absorbed dose and air kerma. 1 Gy = 1 J/kg = 100 rad.
Image display in which intensity is recorded as variations in brightness.
Ability of a grid to absorb scatter radiation.
Absence of optical density on a radiograph caused by unintended x-ray absorption in a grid.
Number of grid lines per inch or centimeter.
Series of sections of radiopaque material.
Ratio of grid height to grid strip separation.
Device used to reduce the intensity of scatter radiation in the remnant x-ray beam.
X-ray tube designed to be turned on and off very rapidly for situations that require multiple exposures at precise exposure times.
Nitrogenous organic base that attaches deoxyribose molecule.
Device in an automatic processor that is used to steer film around bends.
Device that allows the safe introduction of the catheter into the vessel.
Reflection of screen light transmitted through the emulsion and base.
Time required for a quantity of radioactivity to be reduced to half its original value.
Thickness of absorber necessary to reduce an x-ray beam to half its original intensity.
Condition in which the voltage is not allowed to swing negatively during the negative half of its cycle.
Permanent image on film or paper, as opposed to an image on a cathode ray tube, a disc, or magnetic tape.
X-ray that has high penetrability and therefore is of high quality.
A chemical, usually potassium glutaraldehyde alum in the fixer, that is used to stiffen and shrink the emulsion.
Visible parts of the computer.
The science that is concerned with the recognition, evaluation, and control of radiation hazards.
Absorption of x-rays in the heel of the target, resulting in reduced x-ray intensity to the anode side of the central axis.

Form of acute radiation syndrome that develops after whole-body exposure to ranging from approximately 1 to 10 Gy. (100 - 1000 rad). It is characterized by reduction in white cells, red cells, and platelets in circulating blood.
Unit of frequency; the number of cycles or oscillations that occur each second during simple harmonic motion.
Number system used by low-level applications to represent a set of four bits.
Ability to image small objects with high subject contrast; spatial resolution.
One of three principal parts of an x-ray imaging system; it is always close to the x-ray tube.
Radiation interaction with the target.
State of equilibrium among tissue and organs.
Ability of the body to return to normal function despite infection and environmental changes.
Protein manufactured by various endocrine glands and carried by the blood to regulate body functions such as growth and development.
British unit of power
Scale of computed tomographic numbers used to assess the nature of tissue.
Technique that combines temporal and energy subtraction.
Principal compound used in the chemical composition of film developers.
Referring to a body habitus of a patient who is large in frame and overweight.
Undesirable retention of the fixer in emulsion.
Sodium thiosulfate, a fixing agent that removes unexposed and undeveloped silver halide crystals from the emulsion.
Referring to a body habitus of a patient who is thin but healthy looking.
Additional resistance created by the alternate reversal of the magnetic field caused by the alternating current.
Sharpness of small structures on the radiograph.
Electronic vacuum tube that amplifies a fluoroscopic image to reduce patient dose.
Layout of cells in rows and columns.
Deterioration of the radiographic image.
Medium that transforms the x-ray beam into a visible image; radiographic film or a phosphorescent screen.
Contrast that is inherent in the film and is influenced by processing of the film. See also Subject contrast.
X-ray that exits from the patient and enters the image receptor.
Fraction in which the quotient is greater than 1.
In the living cell.
Effect of radiation that results from the production of free radicals produced by the interaction of radiation with water.
Electric motor in which the rotor is a series of wire loops but the external magnetic field is supplied by several fixed electromagnets called stators.
Process of making ferromagnetic material magnetic.
Property of matter that resists change in motion or at rest.
Light that consists of photons with wavelengths longer than those of visible light but shorter than those of microwaves.
Electromagnetic radiation just lower in energy than visible light, with a wavelength in the range of 0.7 to 1000 um (or 700 to 1000 nm)
Filtration of useful x-ray beams provided by the permanently installed components of an x-ray tube housing assembly and the glass window of an x-ray tube.
Time required to start an exposure.
Process of transferring information into primary memory.
Material that inhibits the flow of electrons within a conductor or during heat transfer.
Function of an instrument designed to measure the total accumulated intensity of radiation over time.
Ratio of exposure without screens to produce the same optical density.
Sensitive phosphor that converts x-rays to light to shorten exposure time and reduce patient dose.
Projection formed by the intensity of radiation detected according to the attenuation pattern.
Hardware and software that enable imaging systems to interconnect and to connect with printers.
Naturally occurring radionuclide in the human body.
Standard system of units based on the meter, the kilogram, and the second; it has been adopted by all countries and is used in all branches of science.
Period of growth of the cell between divisions.
Estimation of a value between two known values.
Time during which the signal from an image detector is sampled.
Sections of radiolucent material in a grid.
Referring to the area between cells.
Law that states that the intensity of radiation at a location is inversely proportional to the square of its distance from the source of radiation.
Current that flows from the anode to the cathode.
High-speed switches that convert direct current into a series of square pulses.
Instrument that detects and measures the radiation intensity in areas outside of protective barriers.
Two oppositely charged particles.
Atom with too many or too few electrons; an electrically charged particles.
Bonding that occurs because of an electrostatic force between ions.
Amount of energy (34 eV) necessary to ionize tissue atoms.
Removal of an orbital electron from an atom.
Referring to an atom that has an extra electron or has had an electron removed.
Radiation capable of ionization.
Referring to matter that intercepts radiation and absorbs part or all of it; exposed.
Atoms that have the same number of nucleons but different numbers of protons and neutrons.
Fragment in a chromosome aberration.
Atoms that have the same numbers of protons and neutrons but a different nuclear energy state.
Atoms that have the same number of neutrons.
Atoms that have the same number of protons but a different number of neutrons.
Equal intensity in all directions; having the same properties in all directions.
Unit of energy; the work done when a force of 1 N acts on an object along a distance of 1 m.
Chromosome map.
Energy absorbed per unit mass from the initial kinetic energy released in matter of all the electrons liberated by x-rays or gamma rays. Expressed in gray (Gy). 1 Gy = 1 Jkg.
Prefix meaning one thousand.
The kinetic energy of an electron equivalent to 1000 eV. 1 keV= 1000 eV.
Scientific unit of mass that is unrelated to gravitational effects, 1000 g.
Electric potential equal to 1000 V.
Measure of the maximum electrical potential across an x-ray tube; expressed in kilovolts.
Energy of motion.
Phosphorescence.
Removable disc that uses laser technology to write and read data.
Radiation response that is not observed for 6 months or longer after exposure.
Sensitivity center that has man silver ions attracted to it.
Unobservable image stored in the silver halide emulsion; it is made manifest by processing.
Period after the prodromal stage of acute radiation syndrome during which no sign of radiation sickness is apparent.
Improper positioning of the grid that results in cutoff.
Range of x-ray exposure over which a radiograph is acceptable.
Principle that states the radiosensitivity of cells is directly proportional to their reproductive activity and inversely proportional to their degree of differentiation.
Principle that states that energy may be transformed from one form to another but cannot be created or destroyed; the total amount of energy is constant.
Principle that states the matter can be neither created nor destroyed.
Principle that states that matter a body will remain at rest or will continue to move with a constant velocity in a straight line unless acted on by an external force.
Dose of radiation expected to cause death within 60 days to 50% of those exposed.
Secondary radiation emitted through the tube housing.
Spatial frequency at a modulation transfer function equal to 0.1.
Design incorporated into x-ray tube targets to allow a large area for heating while a small focal spot is maintained.
Projection of an inclined line onto a surface resulting in a smaller size.
One bar and its interspace of equal width.
Measure of the rate at which energy is transferred from ionizing radiation to soft tissue. Expressed in kiloelectron volts per micrometer of soft tissue.
Imaging modality in which the x-ray tube is mechanically attached to the image receptor and moves in one direction as the image receptor moves in the opposite direction.
Referring to the dose-response relationship that intersects the dose axis at or below zero.
Referring to the dose-response relationship that intercepts the dose axis at a value greater than zero.
A leading stone. A natural magnet.
Change in optical density over each exposure interval.
Computer-recognized command that evaluates an intermediate result and performs subsequent computations in accordance with the result.
Low-contrast radiograph that has many shades of gray.
Matrix of data that manipulates the values of gray levels, converting an image input value to a different output value.
Ability to image objects with similar subject contrast.
Emission of visible light.
White blood cell that plays an active role in providing immunity for the body by producing antibodies; it is the most radiosensitive blood cell.
Cell that contains enzymes capable of digesting cellular fragments.
Vector with a magnitude equal to the product of the current that flows in a loop and the area of the current loop.
Current that flows in an infinitesimally small loop.
An accumulation of many atomic magnets with their dipoles aligned.
Property of a material that causes it to attract the imaginary lines of the magnetic field.
The ease with which a substance can be magnetized.
The polarization of a material.
The magnetic oxide of iron.
Relative magnetic flux density in a material compared with that in a vacuum.
Condition in which the images on the radiograph are larger than the object they represent.
Number that represents a quantity.
Breakage of the long-chain macromolecule that divides the long, single molecule into smaller ones.
A fast, medium-to large-capacity system that has multiple microprocessors.
A radiologic technologist who specializes in breast x-ray studies.
Radiographic examination of the breast using low kilovoltage.
Stage of acute radiation syndrome during which signs and symptoms are apparent.
The observable image that is formed when the latent image undergoes proper chemical processing.
X-rays and artificially produced radionuclides used for nuclear medicine.
Image obtained from mask mode.
Method of temporal subtraction that results in successive subtraction images of contrast-filled vessels.
The act of ensuring that no extraneous light from the viewbox enters the viewer's eyes.
Quantity of matter per unit volume.
A quantity of matter; expressed in kilogram.
Energy equals mass multiplied by the square of the speed of light.
Rows and columns of pixels displayed on a digital image.
Anything that occupies space and has form or shape.
Dose of occupational radiation that would be expected to produce no significant radiation effects. An old expression. Replaced by Dose Limit.
Reconstruction of an image through selection of the highest-value pixels along any arbitrary line in the data set; only those pixels are exhibited.
Constant related to the radiosensitivity of a cell.
Average radiation dose to the entire active bone marrow.
Average time between exposure and death.
Ability of an object to do work. See also Kinetic energy and Potential energy.
Physicist who examines and monitors the performance of imaging equipment.
Process of germ cell division that reduces the chromosomes in each daughter cell to half the number of chromosomes in the parent cell.
Anabolism and Catabolism.
Phase of cell division during which the chromosomes are divisible.
Secondary constituent used in the chemical composition of developing agents.
Calcific deposits that appear as small grains of varying sizes on the x-ray film.
Personal computer or electronic organizer.
Tiny computer installed in an appliance.
Tube that has a very small focal spot and that is specifically designed for imaging very small microcalcifications at relatively short source-to-image distances.
Short-wavelength radiofrequency.
Step that has an average optical density closest to, but not less than, 1.2.
Measure of x-ray tube current.
Product of exposure time and x-ray tube current; measure of the total number of electrons.
Ratio of the square of the diameter of the input phosphor to the square of the diameter of the output phosphor.
Misalignment of two or more images because of patient motion between image acquisitions.
Structure that digests macromolecules to produce energy for the cell.
Process of somatic cell division wherein a parent cell divides to form two daughter cells identical to the parent cell.
Device that converts digital information into analog information.
Mathematical procedure for measuring resolution.
Changing of the magnitude of a video signal; the magnitude is directly proportional to the light intensity received by the television camera tube.
Group of atoms of various elements held together by chemical forces; the smallest unit of a compound that can exist by itself and retain all its chemical properties.
Target material for x-ray tubes that is used in mammography.
Product of the mass of an object and its velocity.
Beam that contains x-rays or gamma rays that all have the same energy.
A sugar.
Main circuit board in a system unit.
Blurring of the image that results from movement of the patient or the x-ray tube during exposure.
Grid that moves while the x-ray exposure is being made.
Process by which transverse images are stacked to form a three-dimensional data set.
Imaging modality that uses two detector arrays to produce two spiral slices at the same time.
Model of radiation dose-response relationship for more complicated biologic systems, such as human cells.
Tissue that is capable of contracting. Mutual induction - Process of producing electricity in a secondary coil by passing an alternating current through a nearby primary coil.
Organization that continuously reviews recommended dose limits.
answer: National Council on Radiation Protection and Measurement (NCRP)

question: Naturally occurring ionizing radiation, including cosmic rays, terrestrial radiation, and internally deposited radionuclides.
Magnet that gets its magnetism from the Earth.
Tissue that consists of neurons and serves as the avenue through which electrical impulses are transmitted throughout the body for control and response.
Cell of the nervous system that has long, thin extensions from the cell to distant parts of the body.
Uncharged elementary particle, with a mass slightly greater than that of the proton, that is found in the nucleus of every atom heavier than hydrogen.
Unit of force in the SI System ; 1Nm = 0.22 lb.
One of many stations or terminals of a computer network.
Grainy or uneven appearance of an image caused by an insufficient number of primary x-rays.
Uniform signal produced by scattered x-rays.
Radiation for which the mechanism of action in tissue does not directly ionize or molecular systems through a single interaction.
Referring to varied responses that are produced from varied doses, with a particular level below which there is no response.
Referring to varied responses that are produced from varied doses, with a particular  level below which there is no response.
Maintenance that becomes necessary because of a failure in the system that necessitates processor repair.
Biologic effects of ionizing radiation that demonstrate the existence of a threshold. Severity of biologic damage increases with increased dose. See Determination Effects.
Magnetic pole that has a positive electron charge.
Energy contained within the nucleus of an atom.
Rounded structure that often is attached to the nuclear membrane and controls the passage molecules, especially RNA, from the nucleus to the cytoplasm.
A proton or a neutron.
Unit formed from a nitrogenous base, a five-carbon sugar molecule, and a phosphate molecule.
Center of a living cell; spherical mass of protoplasm that contains the genetic material (DNA) that is stored in its molecular structure.
Center of an atom that contains neutrons and protons.
General term that refers to all known isotopes, both stable and unstable, of chemical elements.
Plane in which the anatomical structures that are to be imaged lie.
Distance from the image receptor to the object that is to be imaged.
Dose received by an individual in a restricted area during the course of employment in which the individual's assigned duties involve exposure to radiation.
Radiation exposure receive by radiation workers.
X-rays produced in the anode but not at the focal spot.
Artifact produced by an improperly positioned radiographic tube-not by an improper positioned grid.
Primordial follicles that grow to encapsulate oogonia.
Surface that does not allow the passage of light.
Condition that results when the filament becomes thinner and breaks.
Console that allows radiologic technologist to control the x-ray tube current and voltage so that the useful x-ray beam is of proper quantity and quality.
Series of instructions that organizes the course of data through the computer to solve a particular problem.
Degree of blackening of a radiograph.
Removable disc that uses laser technology to write and read data.
Notation for coordinates in which the first number of the pair represents a distance along the x-axis and the second number indicates a distance up the y-axis.
Combination of tissues and organs that forms an overall integrated organization.
Molecule that is life supporting and contains carbon.
Collection of tissues of similar structure and function.
Point at which two axes meet on a graph.
Referring to blue- or green-sensitive film; usually exposed with rare Earth screen.
Image interpretation that involves reconciling the patient’s ultimate disease condition with the radiologist’s diagnosis.
Process of transferring the results of a competition from primary memory to storage or to the user.
Protective covering of gelatin that encloses the emulsion.
Referring to a radiograph that is too dark because too much x-radiation reached the image receptor.
Mature germ cell in a female.
Reaction that produces an electron.
Ratio of the dose necessary to produce a given effect under anoxic conditions to the dose necessary to produce the same effect under aerobic conditions.
Interaction between the x-ray and the nuclear electric field that causes the x-ray to disappear and that causes two electrons-one positive and one negative-to take its place.
Referring to film that is sensitive to the entire visible light spectrum.
Circuit that contains elements that bridge conductors rather than lie in a line along a conductor.
Simple grid in which all lead grid strips are parallel.
Referring to materials slightly attracted to a magnet and loosely influenced by an external magnetic field.
Referring to part of the organ that contains tissues representative of that particular organ.
Distortion of signal intensity from a tissue because it extends partially into an adjacent slice thickness.
An atom 'smasher.' Cyclotron. Linear Accelerator.
Radiation distinct from x-rays and gamma rays; examples include alpha particles, electrons, neutrons, and protons.
Ability of an x-ray to penetrate tissue; range in tissue; x-ray quality.
Aluminum step wedge.
Image blur that results from the size of the focal spot; geometric unsharpness.
Magnet whose magnetism is induced artificially.
Device that simulates some parameters of the human body for evaluation of imaging system performance.
Secondary constituent in the chemical composition of developing agents.
Active layer of the radiographic intensifying screen closest to the radiographic film.
Emission of visible light during and after stimulation.
Material that conducts electrons when illuminated.
Solid-state device that converts light into an electric current.
Process by which very high energy x-rays can escape interaction with electrons and the nuclear electric field and can be absorbed directly by the nucleus.
Absorption of an x-ray by ionization.
Electron that has been removed during the process of photoelectric absorption.
Electron emission after light stimulation.
Formation of the latent image.
Instrument that measures light intensity.
Electron tube that converts visible light into an electrical signal.
Electromagnetic radiation that has neither mass nor electric charge but interacts with matter as though it is a particle; x-rays and gamma rays.
Camera that exposes only one frame when active, receiving its image from the output phosphor of the image-intensifier tube.
Emission of visible light after excitation by laser light.
Printing process by which film is exposed to light, thereby forming a latent image that is made by visible by heat.
Device that allows automatic exposure control.
See Spiral pitch ratio.
Picture element; the cell of a digital image matrix.
Fundamental physical constant that relates the energy of radiation to its frequency.
Rollers positioned outside the master roller and guide shoes.
Stem cell that has the ability to develop into several different types of mature cells.
Personnel radiation monitoring device.
Any change that results in impairment or loss of function at the point of a single chemical bond.
Molecular lesion caused by the change or loss of a base that destroys the triplet code and may not be reversible.
Existence of opposing negative and positive charges.
Magnetically charged end of a material.
Referring to radiation, such as x-rays, with a spectrum of energies.
Large carbohydrate that includes starches and glycogen.
Feature of radiographic collimators that automatically adjusts the radiation field to the size of the image receptor.
Compound used as a restrainer in the developer.
Compound used as a restrainer in the developer.
Ability to do work by virtue of position.
Time rate at which work (W) is done. 1 W = 1 J/s.
Exponential form.
An immature cell.
Collimator that restricts the x-ray beam viewed by the detector array.
Collimator that consists of several sections so that a nearly parallel x-ray beam results.
A kVp meter that registers even though an exposure is not being made and no current is flowing within the circuit; this allows the voltage to be monitored before an exposure.
Chemical additive, usually sodium sulfide, which maintains the chemical balance of the developer and fixer.
Planned program of parts replacement at regular intervals.
The first coil through which the varying current in an electromagnet is passed.
Any wall to which the useful beam can be directed.
Chemical treatment of the emulsion of a radiographic film to change a latent image to a manifest image.
Electronic circuitry that does the actual computations and the memory that supports it.
First stage of the acute radiation syndrome; occurs within hours after exposure.
Having the front or ventral surface downward. Lying flat or prostrate.
Fraction in which the quotient is less than 1.
Phase of cell division during which the nucleus and the chromosomes enlarge and the DNA begins to take structural form.
The relation of one part to another.
Sensitive instrument  primarily as stationary laboratory instrument for the assay of small quantities of radioactivity.
Layer of the radiographic intensifying screen closest to the radiographic film.
Lead-lined metal container into which the x-ray tube is fitted.
Metabolic production of proteins.
Elementary particle with a positive electric charge equal to that of an electron and a mass approximately equal to that of a neutron. It is located the nucleus of an atom.
Dose of radiation that is delivered continuously but at a lower dose rate.
Instruments designed to detect the presence of radiation.

All planned and systematic actions necessary to provide adequate confidence that a facility, system, or administrative component will perform safely and satisfactorily in service to a patient. It includes scheduling, preparation, and promptness in examination or treatment, reporting of results, and quality control.
All actions necessary to control and verify the performance of equipment; part of quality assurance.
Radiographic noise produced by the random interaction of x-rays with an intensifying screen. This effect is more noticeable when very high rare Earth systems are used at a high kVp.
Theory in the physics of matter smaller than an atom and of electromagnetic radiation.
An x-ray photon.
Special unit for absorbed dose and air kerma. 1 rad = 100 erg/g = 0.01 Gy.
Transfer of heat by the emission of infrared electromagnetic radiation.
Branch of biology that is concerned with the effects of ionizing radiation on living systems.
X-ray quantity or intensity; measured in roentgens.
Artifact caused by unintentional exposure to radiation.
Theory that suggests that very low radiation doses may be beneficial.
Relative penetrability of an x-ray beam determined by its average energy; usually measured by half-value layer or kilovolt peak.
Intensity of radiation ; usually measured in milliroentgen (mR)
That individual-physician, medical physicist , or technologist-assigned to develop and implement the radiation safety program.
Recommendations , rules , and regulations regarding permissible concentrations, as well as safe handling techniques , transportations , and industrial control of radioactive material.
Factor used for radiation protection that accounts for differences in biologic effectiveness between different radiations. Formerly called quality factor.
Energy emitted and transferred through matter.
Naturally occurring process whereby an unstable atomic nucleus relieves its instability through the emission of one or more energetic particles.
Process by which the nucleus spontaneously emits particles and energy and transforms itself into another atom to reach stability.
Time required for radioisotope to decay to half its original activity.
Rate of decay or disintegration of radioactive material. Expressed in curie (Ci) or bequerel (Bq). 1 Ci = 3.7 x 10 10 Bq.
Electromagnetic radiation with frequencies from 0.3 kHz to 300 GHz; magnetic resonance imaging uses RF in the range of approximately 1 to 100 mHz.
Radiologic technologist who deals specifically with x-ray imaging.
Combined result of image receptor contrast and subject contrast.
Device that converts the energy of the x-ray beam into visible light to increase the brightness of an x-ray image.
Undesirable fluctuation in the optical density of the image.
Guide that describes standard methods for consistently producing high-quality images.
Combination of settings selected on the control panel of the x-ray imaging system to produce a quality image on the radiograph.
Imaging modality that uses x-ray film and usually an x-ray tube mounted from the ceiling on a track that allows the tube to be moved in any direction; provides fixed images.
Radioactive atoms that have the same number of protons. They are changed into a different atomic species by disintegration of the nucleus accompanied by the emission of ionizing radiation.
Scientific society of radiologists and medical physicists.
Physician who specializes in imaging with the use of x-rays, ultrasound, and magnetic resonance imaging.
Referring to a tissue or material that transmits x-rays and appears dark on a radiograph.
Dissociation of water into other molecular products as a result of irradiation.
Any nucleus that emits radiation.
Referring to a tissue or material that transmits x-rays and appears dark on a radiograph.
Relative susceptibility of cells, tissues, and organs to the harmful action of ionizing radiation.
Colorless, odorless, naturally occurring radioactive gas (222Ra) that decays via alpha emission and has a half-life of 3.8 days.
System that consists of at least two disc drives within a single cabinet that collectively act as a single storage system.
answer: RAID (redundant array of inexpensive discs) system

question: Data that can be stored or accessed at random from anywhere in main memory in approximately equal amounts of time, regardless of where they are located.
Element that is a transitional metal found in low abundance in nature.
Radiographic intensifying screen made from rare Earth elements, which make it more useful for radiographic imaging.
Pattern produced on the screen of a television picture tube by the movement of an electron beam or on film by a laser scan.
Mathematical relationship between similar quantities.
Data storage device that contains information supplied by the manufacturer that cannot be written on or erased.
Display for which the image is continuously renewed, often to view anatomical motion, in fluoroscopy and ultrasound.
Principle that states that optical density on a radiograph is proportional only to the total energy imparted to the radiographic film.
Time needed for the computer to present a digital image after an examination has been completed.
Creation of an image from data.
Degree of sharpness of structural lines on a radiograph.
Repair and repopulation.
Process of converting alternating current to direct current.
Electronic device that allows current flow in only one direction.
Filter that transmits light only above 600 nm; it is used with both green- and blue-sensitive film.
Simultaneous reduction and oxidation reactions.
Chemical responsible for reduction.
Process by which an electron is given up by a chemical to neutralize a positive ion.
Return or reentry of an x-ray.
Layer of the intensifying screen that intercepts light headed in other directions and redirects it to the film.
Deviation of course that occurs when photons of visible light traveling in straight lines pass from one transparent medium to another.
Area of an anatomical structure on a reconstructed digital image as defined by the operator using a cursor.
Increased incidence of a disease proportional to its natural incidence.
Ratio of the dose of standard radiation necessary to produce a given effect to the dose of test radiation needed for the same effect.
Estimation of late radiation effects in large populations without precise knowledge of their radiation dose.
Electrical device based on electromagnetic induction that serves as a switch.
Special unit for dose equivalent and effective dose. It has been replaced by the sievert (Sv) in the SI system. 1 rem = 0.01 Sv.
X-rays that pass through the patient and interact with the image receptor.
Replacement of developer and of fixer in the automatic processing of film.
Replication by surviving cells.
Opposition to a force.
Measure of the ability of a system to image two separate objects and visually distinguish one from the other.
Compound that restricts the action of the developing agent to only irradiated silver halide crystals.
Molecules that are involved in the growth and development of a cell through a number of small , spherical cytoplasmic organelles that attach to the endoplasmic reticulum.
The site of protein synthesis.
Rule by which the direction of magnetic field lines can be determined.
One of the three principal film-transport subsystems in an imaging system.
Anode is used in general purpose x-ray tubes because the tubes must be capable of producing high-intensity x-ray beam in a short time.
Rotating part of an electromagnetic induction motor that is located inside the glass envelope.
A carbohydrate
Industry that has an associated annual fatality accident rate of no more than 1 per 10,000 workers.
Incandescent lamp with a color filter that provides sufficient illumination in the darkroom while ensuring that the film remains unexposed.
Any anterior-posterior plane parallel to the long axis of the body.
Filament current that has risen to its maximum value because all available electrons have been used.
Referring to a quantity or a measurement that has only magnitude.
Generalized method of making a digital radiography ; used in computed tomography for precise localization
X-rays scattered back in the direction of the incident x-ray beam.
Procedures performed on a routine basis.
Exponential Forms
Instrument used in the detector arrays of many computed tomographic scanners.
The phosphorescence in an intensifying screens.
Relative number used to identify the efficiency of conversion of x-rays into usable light.
The most commonly used film ; used with intensifying screen.
Imaging examination that is performed on the breasts of asymptomatic women with two-view protocol, to detect unsuspected cancer.
Standard unit of time.
Coil in which induced current in an electromagnetic flows.
Electron ejected from the outer shell of an atom.
Data stored on tape drives , diskettes , and hard disc drivers.
Barrier designed to shield an area from secondary radiation.
Leakage and Scatter Radiation
Unit that incorporates the natural extension of the single detector to a multiple-detector assembly that intercepts a fan-shaped rather than a pencil-shaped x-ray beam.
The thickness of tissue that will not be blurred by tomography.
Ratio of primary radiation to scattered radiation transmitted through the grid.
Magnetic field produced in a coil of wire that opposes the alternating current being conducted.
Imaging system in which the x-ray tube serves as the vacuum-tube rectified.
Material that can serve both as a conductor and as an insulator of electricity.
Physical imperfections in the lattice of the emulsion layer that occur during the film manufacturing process.
Slice thickness
Ability to image receptor to respond to x-rays.
Agent that enhances the effect of radiation.
Optical step wedge that is used to construct a characteristic curve.
Study of the response of an image receptor to x-rays.
Agent introduced into the developer to form stable complexes with metallic ions and salts.
Computer-aided technique that identifies a narrow range of values as belonging to the object to be imaged and displays that range.
Dose of radiation to which the external skin or an extremity is exposed.
Shield that is suspended over the region of interest; it casts a shadow over the patient's reproductive organs.
Type of distortion caused by elongation or foreshortening.
Orbital energy levels that surround the nucleus of an atom.
Transformer that confines more of the magnet field lines of the primary winding because there are essentially two closed cores.
High-contrast radiograph that exhibits black to white in just a few apparent steps.
Special name for the SI unit of dose equivalent and effective dose. 1 Sv = 1 J/kg = 100 rem.
Nonlinear, threshold radiation dose-response relationship.
Material that makes up 98% of the silver halide crystals in a typical emulsion.
Active ingredient of the radiographic emulsion. It is instrumental in creating a latent image on the radiograph.
Material that makes up 2% of the silver halide crystals in a typical emulsion.
Variation in the movement of photons in electrical and magnetic fields.
Model of radiation dose-response relationships for enzymes, viruses, and bacteria.
Simple motion; a sine wave.
Dose of radiation, usually about 200 rad or 2 Gy, that causes redness of the skin.
The thickness of the tissue that is being imaged.
Measure of the efficiency of a multi-slice spiral computed tomographic scanner.
Technology that allows the gantry to rotate continuously without interruption, making spiral computed tomography possible.
Deposit on the film that results from dirty or warped rollers; causes emulsion pickoff and gelatin buildup.
Alkali compound contained in the developer.
Alkali compound contained in the developer.
Preservative added to the developer that keeps it clear.
Output on a display screen.
Radiography in which only muscle and fat structures are imaged.
X-ray that has low penetrability and therefore is of low quality.
Computer programs that tell the hardware what to do and how to store data.
Helical winding of current-carrying wire that produces a magnetic field along the axis of the helix.
Diode that passes electric current in only one direction.
Suspension of particles or molecules in a fluid.
Liquid into which various solids and powders can be dissolved.
All cells of the body except the oogonium and the spermatogonium.
Effects of radiation, such as cancer and leukemia, limited to an exposed individual. See also Genetic effect.
Distance from the x-ray tube to the image receptor.
Distance from patient's skin to the fluoroscopic tube.
Electron cloud near the filament.
Phenomenon of the space charge that makes it difficult for subsequent electrons to be emitted by the filament because of electrostatic repulsion.
Misrepresentation in the image of the actual spatial relationships among objects.
Measure of resolution; usually expressed in line pairs per millimeter (lp/mm)
Ability to image small objects that have high subject contrast.
Constancy of pixel values in all regions of the reconstructed image.
Additional quantities designed to support measurement in specialized areas of science and technology.
Use of Rare Earth screens only in conjunction with film emulsions that have light absorption characteristics matched to the light emission of the screen.
Graphic representation of the range over which a quantity extends.
Step that has an average optical density closest to, but not less than. 1.2.
Term used to loosely describe the sensitivity of film to x-rays.
See Spermatozoa.
Mature spermatogonium.
Male germ cell.
Functionally mature male germ cell.
Fibers that connect a centromere and two chromatids to the poles of the nucleus during mitosis.
Poles of the nucleus.
Device used to check exposure timers.
Relationship between patient couch movement and x-ray beam collimation.
Term given to computed tomography because it describes the apparent motion of the x-ray tube during the scan.
Static image in a small-format image receptor taken during fluoroscopy.
Principle that states that one can compensate for a change in the source-to-object distance by changing the mAs by the factor SID squared.
A plant polysaccharide.
Anode used in imaging systems in which high tube current and power are not required.
Stationary coil windings located in the protective housing but outside the x-ray tube glass envelope. It is part of the electromagnetic induction motor.
Immature or precursor cell.
Filter used during radiography of a body part, such as the foot, that varies in thickness from one end to the other.
Transformer in which the voltage is decreased from the primary side to the secondary side.
Computer-controlled capability on a patient table that allows imaging from the abdomen to the feet after a single injection of contrast media.
Transformer in which the voltage is increased from the primary side to the secondary side.
Practice of making two radiographs  of the same object and viewing through a device that allows each eye to view a different radiographs.
Referring to the body habitus of a patient who is strong and active; average body habitus.
Probability or frequency of the biologic response to radiation as a function of radiation dose. Disease incidence increases proportionally with dose, and there is no dose threshold.
Main computer memory in which the program and data files are stored.
Portion of Sensitometric Curve in which the diagnostic or most useful range of density is produced.
Referring to part of an organ that is composed of connective tissue and vasculature that provides  structure of the organ.
Distribution of phosphor crystals in an intensifying screen.
Particle smaller than atom.

Component of radiographic contrast determined by the size, shape, and x-ray attenuating characteristics of the subject who is being examined and the energy of the x-ray beam. See also Image receptor Contrast.
Any drug, chemical, or biologic entity.
Method of removing all unnecessary anatomical structures from an image and enhancing only those of interest.
One of the fastest and highest-capacity computers; contains hundreds to thousands of microprocessors.
Property by which some materials exhibit no resistance below a critical temperature.
Lying down with the face up. The ventral side is up, the dorsal side is down.
Tissue that binds tissues and organs together.
Molecules (DNA) that are few in number yet essential for cell survival; they are particularly sensitive to the effects of ionizing radiation.
Theory that a cell will die if target molecules are inactivated as a result of radiation exposure.
Region of an x-ray tube anode that is struck by electrons emitted by the filament.
Molecule (DNA) that is most sensitive to radiation.
The kVp and mA as selected for a given radiographic examination.
Transfer of images and patient reports to remote sites.
Final subphase of mitosis that is characterized by the disappearance of structural chromosomes into a mass of DNA and the closing off of the nuclear membrane into two nuclei.
Measure of heat and cold.
Computer-assisted technique whereby an image obtained at a later time.
Magnet that retains the properties of a magnet only while its magnetism is being induced.
Thickness of an absorber necessary to reduce an x-ray beam to one-tenth its original intensity. 1 TVL = 3.3 half-value layers.
Input and output device that uses a keyboard input and a display screen for output.
Radiation emitted from deposits of uranium, thorium, and other radionuclides in the Earth.
SI unit of magnetic field intensity. An older unit is the gauss (G) . 1 T = 10, 000 G.
Passive device that provides echoes and permits evaluation of one or more parameters of an ultrasound system but does not necessarily duplicate the acoustic properties of the human body.
Passive device that provides echoes and permits evaluation of one or more parameters of an ultrasound systems but not necessarily duplicate the acoustic properties of the human body.
Passive device of geometric shapes designed to evaluate the performance of x-ray and magnetic resonance imaging systems. See also Phantom.
Energy of molecular motion; heat; infrared radiation.
Transfer of heat by infrared emission.
Emission  of electrons from a heated surface.
Process that uses only heat to produce a visible image on film.
Emission of light by a thermally stimulated crystal after irradiation.
Device that measures temperature.
Fixing agent that removes unexposed and undeveloped silver halide crystals from the emulsion.
Generation of three simultaneous voltage waveforms out of step with one another; thus, voltage never drops to zero during exposure.
Dose below which a person has a negligible chance of sustaining specific biologic damage, or dose at which response to increasing x-ray intensity first occurs.
Circular or oval disc called a platelet; it is found in the blood, and it initiates blood clotting and prevents hemorrhage.
Number of patients imaged per day. Number of films imaged per hour.
Nitrogenous organic base that attaches to a deoxyribose molecule.
Technique that produces subtracted images from progressive masks and the frames that follow.
Length of time that the area being protected is used.

Proportion of risk of stochastic effects that result from irradiation of the whole body when only an organ or tissue is irradiated; accounts for the relative radiosensitivity of various tissues and organs.
Collection of cells of similar structure and function.
X-ray image of a coronal, sagittal, transverse, or oblique section through the body.
Imaging modality that brings into focus only the anatomical structure lying in a plane of interest, while structures on either side of that plane are blurred.
Recommendation by National Council on Radiation Protection and Measurement that a radiation worker's lifetime effective dose should be limited to the worker's age in years multiplied by 10 mSv.
Inherent filtration plus added filtration.
Across the body; transverse.
Process of constructing mRNA.
Addition of an amino acid during translation.
Electrical device that operates on the principle of mutual induction to change the magnitude of current and voltage.
Process of forming a protein molecule from messenger RNA.
Surface that allows light to be transmitted but greatly alters and reduces its intensity.
Passage of an x-ray beam through an anatomical part with no interaction with atomic structures.
Surface that allows light to be transmitted almost unaltered.
Agent that moves the film through chemical tanks and the dryer assembly.
Image that is perpendicular to the long axis of the body.
Across the body; axial.
Metal element that is the principal component of the cathode and the anode.
Device in the automatic processor that reverses the direction of film.
Quotient of the number of turns in the secondary coil to the number of turns in the primary coil.
Light that is located at the short end of the electromagnetic spectrum between visible light and ionizing x-rays; it is beyond the range of human vision.
Area occupied by anyone; the maximum exposure rate allowed in this area is based on the recommended dose limit for the public.
Referring to a radiograph that is too light because too little x-radiation reaches the image receptor.
Immature or nonspecialized cell.
Theoretical combination of magnetic, electric, gravitational, and strong nuclear forces, along with weak interaction, to explain the physical laws of magnetism.
Standard of measurement.
Proportional amount of time during which the x-ray beam is energized or directed toward a particular barrier.
Primary radiation used to form an image.
Electron in the outermost shell.
Box-shaped device that contains a radiographic beam-defining system. It is the device that is most often used to reduce the size and shape of a radiographic beam.
Abbreviation for video display terminal.
Quantity or measurement that has magnitude, unit, and direction.
Rate of change of an object's position over time; speed.
Monitor that is similar to a television screen.
Television camera tube that is used most often in television fluoroscopy.
Reduction in brightness at the periphery of the image.
Radiant energy in the electromagnetic spectrum that is visible to the human eye.
SI unit of electric potential and potential difference.
Means of characterizing voltage waveforms.
Stack of copper and zinc plates that produces an electric current; a precursor of the modern battery.
Three-dimensional pixel; volume element.
Stage of processing during which any remaining chemicals are removed from the film.
One ampere of current that flows through an electric potential of one volt.
Formula that states that velocity equals frequency multiplied by wavelength.
Theory that electromagnetic energy travels through space in the form of waves.
Graphic representation of a wave.
Distance between similar points on a sine wave; the length of one cycle.
Principle that states that both wave and particle concepts must be retained, because wave-like properties are exhibited in some experiments and particle-like properties are exhibited in others.
Force on a mass that is caused by the acceleration of gravity. Properly expressed in new commonly expressed in newtons (N), but commonly expressed in pounds (lb). 4.4 lb = 1 N.
Agent, usually water, that threats the radiograph so that chemicals can penetrate the emulsion.
Process that makes the emulsion film swell so that subsequent chemical baths can reach the emulsion uniformly.
For purposes of external exposure, the head, trunk (including gonads), arm above and elbow , and the leg above the knee.
Radiographic exposure in which the whole body, rather than an isolate part , is irradiated.
Location on a digital image number scale at which the levels of grays are assigned. It regulates the optical density of the displayed image and  identifies the type of tissue to be imaged.
Specific number of gray levels or digital image numbers assigned to an image. It determines gray scale rendition of the imaged tissue and therefore image contrast.
Thin section of a glass envelope through which the useful beam emerges.
Technique that allows one to see only a 'window' of the entire dynamic range.
Two bytes of information.
Product of the force on an object and the distance over which the force acts. Expressed in joules (J). W = F x d.
Product of the maximum milliamperage (mA) and the number of x-ray examinations performed per week. Expressed in milliamperes per minute per week (mA/min/wk).
Powerful desktop system; often connected to larger computer systems so that users can transfer and share information.
Horizontal line of a graph.
X-ray system designed for radiography, tomography, or fluoroscopy.
Penetrability of an x-ray beam.
Output intensity of an X-ray imaging system; measured in roentgens (R).
Charts that guide the technologist in the use of x-ray tubes.
Penetrating, ionizing electromagnetic radiation that has a wavelength much shorter than that of visible light.
Vertical line of a graph.
Thick-slice tomography with a tomographic angle of less than 10 degrees.
